Description: OBJECTIVES: TO REHABILITATE THE MAIDEN PASSIVE SYSTEM IN ORDER TO CONTINUE TREATMENT OF THE ABANDONED MINE DISCHARGE AND RESTORATION OF DUNKARD CREEK. PROJECT DESCRIPTION: THE MAIDEN PASSIVE TREATMENT SYSTEM (MAIDEN PTS) IN DUNKARD TOWNSHIP, GREENE COUNTY WAS ORIGINALLY INSTALLED ON PRIVATE PROPERTY IN 2006 TO ADDRESS TWO ABANDONED MINE DISCHARGES INCLUDING ONE OF THE LARGEST SOURCES OF ACIDIC AMD IN THE DUNKARD CREEK WATERSHED. THE PROJECT WAS COMPLETED AS PART OF A VAST PUBLIC-PRIVATE PARTNERSHIP EFFORT TO RESTORE DUNKARD CREEK WHICH WAS BEING IMPACTED BY OLD, ABANDONED COAL MINES. THIS PARTNERSHIP INCLUDED WATERSHED AND NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, GOVERNMENT ENTITIES, PRIVATE COMPANIES AND LOCAL CITIZENS. ABOUT ONE YEAR AFTER COMPLETION, THE LANDOWNER REVOKED ALL PERMISSIONS TO ENTER THE PROPERTY WHICH PREVENTED MONITORING AND MAINTENANCE OF THE SYSTEM. STREAM RESTORATION INCORPORATED AND VARIOUS PROJECT PARTNERS SPENT SEVERAL YEARS AND THOUSANDS OF DOLLARS ATTEMPTING TO A NEW AGREEMENT AND AT ONE POINT EVEN TRIED TO PURCHASE THE PROPERTY WITHOUT SUCCESS. THE TREATMENT SYSTEM WAS THOUGHT TO BE LOST. THEN IN 2015, MEPCO, LLC SPECIFICALLY PURCHASED THE PROPERTY FOR THE PURPOSE OF PROVIDING SRI ACCESS TO OPERATE, MAINTAIN, MONITOR, REHABILITATE AND IMPROVE THE MAIDEN PTS. AFTER ALMOST 10 YEARS OF TREATING HIGHLY ACIDIC AND METAL LADEN WATER WITH NO MAINTENANCE, THE SYSTEM WAS FOUND TO BE IN VERY POOR CONDITION. THE AMD WAS ESSENTIALLY BYPASSING MOST OF THE TREATMENT COMPONENTS. FUNDING WAS PULLED TOGETHER FROM MULTIPLE SOURCES TO RESTORE THE FUNCTIONALITY OF THE EXISTING COMPONENTS AS FEASIBLE. THIS INITIAL PHASE WAS COMPLETED IN 2016. WHILE SIGNIFICANT IMPROVEMENTS IN WATER QUALITY WERE ACHIEVED, ADDITIONAL MAINTENANCE AND IMPROVEMENTS ARE NEEDED INCLUDING EXPANDING EXISTING TREATMENT CAPABILITY. WORK TO BE COMPLETED INCLUDES CLEANING OF LIMESTONE, ADDING ADDITIONAL TREATMENT MEDIA, AND CONVERTING THE EXISTING HORIZONTAL FLOW LIMESTONE BED TO A MIXED MEDIA JENNINGSSTYLE VERTICAL FLOW POND. COMBINED WITH THE EFFORTS OF MEPCO, LLC THESE PROPOSED EFFORTS ARE EXPECTED TO SIGNIFICANTLY IMPROVE DUNKARD CREEK. ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS: THIS PROJECT IS EXPECTED TO REHABILITATE THE MAIDEN PASSIVE TREATMENT SYSTEM. ONCE COMPLETED THE SYSTEM IS EXPECTED TO TREAT AN ESTIMATED 150 MILLION GALLONS OF AMD PER YEAR RESULTING IN THE NEUTRALIZATION OF MORE THAN 100,000 LB YEAR OF ACIDITY AND THE PREVENTION OF MORE THAN 25,000 LB YEAR OF IRON AND 20,000 LB YEAR OF ALUMINUM FROM ENTERING DUNKARD CREEK. RESTORING THE TREATMENT SYSTEM WILL HELP TO MAINTAIN THE IMPROVEMENT GAINS TO THE WATER QUALITY AND AQUATIC LIFE OF DUNKARD CREEK. PROJECT PARTNERS: BIOMOST, INC.  MEPCO, LLC  PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION  STREAM RESTORATION INCORPORATED

WESTERN PENNSYLVANIA COALTION FOR ABANDONED MINE RECLAMATION (WPCAMR) IS A 501C3, NON PROFIT ORGANIZATION THATSERVES AS THE FISCAL SPONSOR FOR PENNSYLVANIAS QUICK RESPONSE PROGRAM. QUICK RESPONSE PROVIDES REPAIRASSISTANCE EMERGENCY OR URGENT MAINTENANCE REPAIRS OF BMPS THROUGHOUT THE COMMONWEALTH. THIS PROPOSAL WILLSUPPLEMENT QUICK RESPONSE ROUND 10 FUNDING. WPCAMR HAS BEEN ADMINISTERING THIS PROGRAM SINCE 2006. EXPERIENCEWITH THE NINE PREVIOUS ROUNDS OF FUNDING THROUGH PENNSYLVANIAS GROWING GREENER PROGRAM SHOWS THAT THE MAJORITYOF PROJECTS AIDED BY QUICK RESPONSE ARE ABANDONED MINE DRAINAGE (AMD) TREATMENT SYSTEMS.OVER 300 AMD TREATMENT SYSTEMS HAVE BEEN CONSTRUCTED BY LOCAL NON-PROFITS AND COUNTY CONSERVATION DISTRICTSTHROUGH COMBINATION OF COMMONWEALTH, LOCAL, FOUNDATION, AND FEDERAL GRANT FUNDS. EACH OF THESE SYSTEMS IMPROVESWATER QUALITY OF THEIR RECEIVING STREAM AND IF THE SYSTEM FAILS TO WORK DUE TO LACK OF FUNDS FOR OPERATIONS,MAINTENANCE AND REPAIRS, THOSE STREAM IMPROVEMENTS WILL REVERT. NEARLY ALL OF THESE SYSTEMS ARE OPERATED BYVOLUNTEERS AND ONLY A FEW OF THEM HAVE DEDICATED FUNDS FOR OPERATIONS, MAINTENANCE, AND REHABILITATION NEEDS,EITHER SCHEDULED OR EMERGENCY. THIS MEANS THAT MOST REPAIRS ARE FUNDED ON AN AS-NEEDED BASIS THROUGH FUNDRAISINGAND GRANT-WRITING.THE QUICK RESPONSE PROGRAM PROVIDES FUNDS, UPON REQUEST AND PROPER APPROVAL, TO ANY PHYSICAL FACILITY THAT ISOTHERWISE ELIGIBLE TO APPLY FOR GROWING GREENER GRANTS, ESPECIALLY AMD TREATMENT SYSTEMS. A HIGHLIGHT OF THISPROGRAM IS THE SPEED AT WHICH WPCAMR SERVES AS A PASS THROUGH AND CAN ADDRESS EMERGENCY SITUATIONS THAT ARISE ASWELL AS CORRECTING EMERGENT ISSUES BEFORE THEY CAUSE TREATMENT SYSTEM FAILURE AND IMPACT WATER QUALITY THAT ISIMPROVED THROUGH TREATMENT.PROJECT PARTNERS INCLUDE PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION, ALL PENNSYLVANIA COUNTYCONSERVATION DISTRICTS WHO OPERATE AMD TREATMENT SYSTEMS, ALL PENNSYLVANIA NON-PROFITS WHO OPERATE AMD TREATMENTSYSTEMS.SPECIFIC DELIVERABLES INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING:DELIVERABLE 1: FISCAL ADMINISTRATION OF THE PROJECTDELIVERABLE 2: CONTRACTUAL SERVICES FOR THE REPAIR OF BMPS

ROARING CREEK PASSIVE TREATMENT INSTALLATION:CONTINUATION OF THE NORTH PORTAL PROJECTPROJECT ABSTRACTTHE MARS PORTALS SITES ON ROARING CREEK, IN RANDOLPH COUNTY, WV CONSIST OF A DRAINING, OPEN PORTAL (MARS PORTAL1), A COLLAPSED PORTAL (MARS PORTAL 2), AND A PORTAL THAT WAS RECLAIMED BY THE WEST VIRGINIA OFFICE OF ABANDONEDMINE LANDS AND RECLAMATION (WV AML) WITH A WET SEAL (NORTH PORTAL). THESE ACID MINE DRAINAGE (AMD) SOURCES MAKEUP THE HEADWATERS FOR KITTLE HOLLOW AND ARE A MAJOR SOURCE OF ACIDITY AND METALS ASSOCIATED WITH A LEGACY OF COALMINING PRACTICES IN THE AREA. THE NORTH PORTAL PROJECT IS THE FIRST IN A SERIES OF PROJECTS AIMED AT REMOVINGROARING CREEK (WV  MT-42) FROM THE STATES 2014 303(D) LIST OF IMPAIRED STREAMS (WVDEP, 2014). THE PROPOSEDTREATMENT AREA FOR THE PROJECT CONSISTS OF AN AREA ADJACENT TO THE WET-SEALED NORTH PORTAL WHICH IS SCRUB ANDNEARLY BARREN GRASSLAND. PROPOSED TREATMENT FOR THIS PROJECT WILL ENTAIL THE CONSTRUCTION OF OPEN LIMESTONECHANNELS (OLC) TO DIRECT THE WATER, LIMESTONE LEACHBEDS TO PROVIDE TREATMENT, AND WETLANDS SETTLING PONDS TOCOLLECT THE METALS IN THE EFFLUENT AND POLISH THE WATER BEFORE IT ENTERS KITTLE HOLLOW. THE OBJECTIVE OF THISRECLAMATION PROJECT IS TO ASSIST IN BRINGING ROARING CREEK WITHIN ALLOWABLE TMDL LIMITS AND THE EVENTUAL REMOVALOF ROARING CREEK FROM THE 303(D) LIST OF IMPAIRED WATERS. THIS WCAP FUNDING WILL PROVIDE A MATCH FOR 319 FUNDINGINTENDED TO COMPLETE PREVIOUS WORK ON THE NORTH PORTAL EFFLUENT. THE DIRECT GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO REMOVEROUGHLY 80  OF THE FE AND AL FROM THE NORTH PORTAL, WHILE INCREASING PH AND ALSO REMOVING MN AND THE OVERALL ACIDLOAD ENTERING KITTLE HOLLOW AND EVENTUALLY ROARING CREEK. THE MAIN GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO RE-ESTABLISH AVIABLE AQUATIC ECOSYSTEM IN THE KITTLE HOLLOW AND ROARING CREEK THIS TRANSLATES TO A HEALTHY MACROINVERTEBRATEPOPULATION COUPLED WITH A STRONG FISH POPULATION. THIS PROJECT, ALONG WITH THE EVENTUAL PROJECTS TO TREAT THEOTHER MARS PORTALS, ARE THE FIRST STEPS IN REVIVING THIS INTENSELY DEGRADED ECOSYSTEM.

SEWICKLEY CREEK WATERSHED ASSOCIATIONS (SCWA) MISSION IS TO PROTECT AND RESTORE THE QUALITY OF NATURAL RESOURCESIN THE SEWICKLEY CREEK WATERSHED. IN ORDER TO DO THIS, THE ASSOCIATION SEEKS OUT AND COOPERATES WITH GOVERNMENTAGENCIES, INTERESTED ORGANIZATIONS, BUSINESSES, AND INDIVIDUALS IN ORDER TO IMPLEMENT PROGRAMS THAT IMPROVE WATERQUALITY AND ENCOURAGE PROPER LAND USE. THE WATERSHED ASSOCIATION ALSO USES ITS RESOURCES TO EDUCATE THE CITIZENSOF THE WATERSHED ON HOW TO USE OR IMPLEMENT SOUND ENVIRONMENTAL PRACTICES.THE WATERSHED ASSOCIATION IS A NON-PROFIT 501(C) ORGANIZATION, AND ALL CONTRIBUTIONS TO THIS ORGANIZATION ARE TAXDEDUCTIBLE.THE BRINKERTON MINE DRAINAGE TREATMENT SYSTEM WAS CONSTRUCTED IN 2008. THE SYSTEM WAS INSTALLED USING FUNDINGFROM MANY SOURCES INCLUDING GRANTS AND PRIVATE DONATIONS. THE TREATMENT SYSTEM HAS WORKED EFFECTIVELY AT REMOVINGTHE IRON FROM THE MINE DRAINAGE. THE SYSTEM IS ON PROPERTY OWNED AND OPERATED BY THE SCWA. THE SCWA HAS PERFORMEDROUTINE OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF THE FACILITY TO THE BEST OF THEIR ABILITIES, HOWEVER THEY HAVE LIMITEDRESOURCES. PART OF PASSIVE MINE DRAINAGE SYSTEM MAINTENANCE IS REMOVAL OF THE ACCUMULATED IRON. MAINTENANCE ISNEEDED TO HELP KEEP THE SYSTEM FUNCTIONING PROPERLY SINCE IT IS BEING OVERBURDENED FROM THE ACCUMULATION OF IRON.THE HOLDING CAPACITY IS BEING DIMINISHED FROM THE IRON DEPOSITS. IN 2022, THE SYSTEM HAD ITS FIRST IRON REMOVALIN 17 YEARS, ADDITIONAL IRON REMOVAL IS NEEDED. THIS PROJECT, WOULD CONSIST OF CONTINUING TO REMOVE IRON,INCREASE WATER OXIDATION WITH THE ONSITE BLOWERS, AND IMPROVE WATER FLOW AND VEGETATION MANAGEMENT. THE GOAL OFTHIS WOULD BE TO IMPROVE AND SUSTAIN THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE BRINKERTON MINE PASSIVE TREATMENT SYSTEM. THEMETHODS THIS PROJECT WOULD USE IS TO HIRE A CONTRACTOR TO REMOVE THE IRON SLUDGE, CONTINUE TO OPERATE THEMAELSTROM OXIDIZER AND MONITOR ITS EFFECTIVENESS WITHIN THE TREATMENT SYSTEM, CONTINUE TO MANAGE VEGETATION ONTHE EMBANKMENTS TO ENSURE TREE ROOTS DO NOT COMPROMISE THE SYSTEM, AND HAULING ORGANIC SLUDGE FROM THE SITE. THEIMPROVEMENTS TO THIS SYSTEM WOULD HAVE A LASTING EFFECT ON SEWICKLEY CREEK S WATER QUALITY. IF THE BRINKERTONMINE DRAINAGE CAN BE EFFECTIVELY TREATED, THERE IS GREAT OPPORTUNITY TO EXPAND THE DESIGNATED USES OF SEWICKLEYCREEK INCLUDING THE CONTINUATION OF TROUT STOCKING DOWNSTREAM FROM THE SYSTEM. THE MAJOR PARTNERS INVOLVED INTHIS PROJECT WITH SEWICKLEY CREEK WATERSHED ASSOCIATION ARE PENNSYLVANIA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION,WESTMORELAND CONSERVATION DISTRICT AND MOUNT PLEASANT TOWNSHIP TO HELP WITH THE REMEDIATION EFFORTS.

JAGER SOUTH ABSTRACTPATHFINDERS RCAND D IS PARTNERING WITH THE MAHASKA COUNTY SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT AND THE IOWADEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE AND LAND STEWARDSHIP DIVISION OF SOIL CONSERVATION AND WATER QUALITY (THE DIVISION) TOADDRESS ACID MINE DRAINAGE FROM THE JAGER ABANDONED MINE LAND SITE. THE SITE POSES A WATER QUALITY RESOURCECONCERN. THIS CONCERN STEMS FROM HIGH SEDIMENT LOADS COMING FROM DANGEROUS BARREN SPOIL PILES LEFT FROM PREVIOUSCOAL MINING ACTIVITY AND ACID MINE DRAINAGE (AMD) FROM UNCONTROLLED RUNOFF AT THE SITE.OVERALL PROJECT DESCRIPTION  THIS PROJECT IS DIVIDED INTO A NORTH AND SOUTH PORTION DUE TO THE PRESENCE OF 320THSTREET DIVIDING THE SITE INTO TWO DIFFERENT SECTIONS. THE ANTICIPATED WORK WILL BE TO CONCENTRATE ON ONE SIDE OFTHE SITE AT A TIME, AND HAVE MINIMAL DISTURBANCE CROSSING 320TH STREET. THE SITE WILL BLEND INTO THE EXISTINGLANDSCAPE BY USING THE NATURAL REGRADE ENGINEERING DESIGN. BOTH NORTH AND SOUTH PORTIONS WILL HAVE A WETLANDPRESENT. THE PROJECT WITH THEN BE SEEDING DOWN WITH AN UPLAND SEEDING MIX TO PROVIDE COVER.THE JAGER SOUTH RECLAMATION PROJECT IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 1.5 MILES NORTHEAST OF THE EDDYVILLE RACEWAY PARK.THE APPROXIMATELY 21.6 ACRE ABANDONED MINE LAND (AML) SITE WAS MINED PRIOR TO 1977. THE RECLAMATION PROJECT WILLELIMINATE THE COAL MINING FEATURES THAT PRESENT A DANGER TO THE HEALTH AND SAFETY OF THE PUBLIC AND RESULTINGACID MINE DRAINAGE. THE SITE IS 2 MILES FROM THE DES MOINES RIVER, WHICH IS ACTIVELY USED FOR RECREATION AND THECURRENT CONDITION OF THE SITE NEGATIVELY IMPACTS AN UN NAMED TRIBUTARY. THIS DRAINAGE THEN FLOWS SOUTHWEST INTOTHE LOST CREEK, WHICH THEN FLOWS INTO THE DES MOINES RIVER. THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO RECLAIM THE PROJECTAREA TO ALLEVIATE AML PRIORITY FEATURES AND ESTABLISH A PERMANENT SEEDING TO STABILIZE THE SITE.THE SITE DESIGN RE ESTABLISHES PRE MINING DRAINAGE PATTERNS INCLUDING TWO DRAINAGE WAYS AND A WETLAND. ACCORDINGTO THE PROJECT DESIGN, CONSTRUCTION WILL ABATE ALL THE HAZARDOUS ABANDONED MINE LAND FEATURES. THE CONSTRUCTIONCONTRACT WILL CLEAR, RE GRADE AND RE VEGETATE APPROXIMATELY 21.6 ACRES USE THE NATURAL REGRADE DESIGN FORRECLAMATION. THIS METHOD USES THE LANDSCAPE TO CREATE SMALL TRIBUTARIES THAT CARRY WATER INTO ONE LARGERMEANDERING STREAM. THE IOWA AML PROGRAM HAS OVERSEEN MORE THAN 53 SIMILAR, AND SUCCESSFUL, RECLAMATION AND AMDREMEDIATION PROJECTS.NO INDIVIDUAL, BUSINESS OR POLITICAL SUBDIVISION HAS ANY LEGAL RESPONSIBILITY TO RECLAIM THE SITE. WATERSHEDCOOPERATIVE AGREEMENT PROGRAM (WCAP) FUNDS WILL BE MATCHED BY STATE AND LOCAL FUNDS TO COMPLETE THE JAGER SOUTHRECLAMATION PROJECT. PATHFINDERS RCAND D WILL WORK WITH THE STATE OF IOWA S AML PROGRAM TO RECLAIM THE SITE. FUNDSWILL BE USED FOR EARTHMOVING, WATER AND SOIL NEUTRALIZATION, AND SEEDING ACTIVITIES TO ELIMINATE THE ACID MINEDRAINAGE ORIGINATING FROM THIS SITE. THE TOTAL RECLAMATION CONSTRUCTION COST IS ESTIMATED AT  476,289.10. TOTALPROJECT COSTS ARE ESTIMATED AT  578,752.10.UPON COMPLETION OF RECLAMATION, WILDLIFE HABITAT AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES WILL BE ENHANCED, PROVIDINGECONOMIC AND HEALTH BENEFITS TO ALL IOWANS. RECLAMATION WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT WATER QUALITY AND SOIL HEALTH ONTHE SITE, AS WELL AS, IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND SOIL HEALTH IN ADJACENT WATERBODIES AND FIELDS IN THE COUNTY OVERTIME THROUGH THE INTERCONNECTEDNESS OF THE WATER CYCLE AND SOIL SYSTEMS.

THERE IS ONE MAIN UNNAMEDDRAINAGE WAY IN THE JAGER NORTH PROJECT THAT FLOWS THROUGH THE SITE FROM NORTH TO SOUTH, FLOWS THROUGH A METALCULVERT UNDER 320TH STREET, AND INTO THE JAGER SOUTH SITE. THIS DRAINAGE THEN FLOWS SOUTHWEST INTO THE UNNAMEDTRIBUTARY TO LOST CREEK, WHICH THEN FLOWS INTO THE DES MOINES RIVER. THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO RECLAIM THEPROJECT AREA TO ALLEVIATE AML PRIORITY FEATURES AND ESTABLISH A PERMANENT SEEDING TO STABILIZE THE SITE.THE SITE DESIGN RE ESTABLISHES PRE MINING DRAINAGE PATTERNS INCLUDING ONE SMALL DRAINAGE WAY AND TWO WETLANDS.ACCORDING TO THE PROJECT DESIGN, CONSTRUCTION WILL ABATE ALL THE HAZARDOUS ABANDONED MINE LAND FEATURES. THECONSTRUCTION CONTRACT WILL CLEAR, RE GRADE AND RE VEGETATE APPROXIMATELY 32.4 ACRES USE THE NATURAL REGRADEDESIGN FOR RECLAMATION. THIS METHOD USES THE LANDSCAPE TO CREATE SMALL TRIBUTARIES THAT CARRY WATER INTO ONELARGER MEANDERING STREAM. THE IOWA AML PROGRAM HAS OVERSEEN MORE THAN 53 SIMILAR, AND SUCCESSFUL, RECLAMATION ANDAMD REMEDIATION PROJECTS.NO INDIVIDUAL, BUSINESS OR POLITICAL SUBDIVISION HAS ANY LEGAL RESPONSIBILITY TO RECLAIM THE SITE. WATERSHEDCOOPERATIVE AGREEMENT PROGRAM (WCAP) FUNDS WILL BE MATCHED BY STATE AND LOCAL FUNDS TO COMPLETE THE JAGER NORTHRECLAMATION PROJECT. PATHFINDERS RCAND D WILL WORK WITH THE STATE OF IOWA S AML PROGRAM TO RECLAIM THE SITE. FUNDSWILL BE USED FOR EARTHMOVING, WATER AND SOIL NEUTRALIZATION, AND SEEDING ACTIVITIES TO ELIMINATE THE ACID MINEDRAINAGE ORIGINATING FROM THIS SITE. THE TOTAL RECLAMATION CONSTRUCTION COST IS ESTIMATED AT  714,433.65. TOTALPROJECT COSTS ARE ESTIMATED AT  816,896.65.UPON COMPLETION OF RECLAMATION, WILDLIFE HABITAT AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES WILL BE ENHANCED, PROVIDINGECONOMIC AND HEALTH BENEFITS TO ALL IOWANS. RECLAMATION WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT WATER QUALITY AND SOIL HEALTH ONTHE SITE, AS WELL AS, IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND SOIL HEALTH IN ADJACENT WATERBODIES AND FIELDS IN THE COUNTY OVERTIME THROUGH THE INTERCONNECTEDNESS OF THE WATER CYCLE AND SOIL SYSTEMS.

MCCREA ABSTRACTPATHFINDERS RCAND D IS PARTNERING WITH THE MAHASKA COUNTY SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT AND THE IOWADEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE AND LAND STEWARDSHIP DIVISION OF SOIL CONSERVATION AND WATER QUALITY (THE DIVISION) TOADDRESS ACID MINE DRAINAGE FROM THE MCCREA ABANDONED MINE LAND SITE. THE SITE POSES A WATER QUALITY RESOURCECONCERN. THIS CONCERN STEMS FROM HIGH SEDIMENT LOADS COMING FROM DANGEROUS BARREN SPOIL PILES LEFT FROM PREVIOUSCOAL MINING ACTIVITY AND ACID MINE DRAINAGE (AMD) FROM UNCONTROLLED RUNOFF AT THE SITE.THE MCCREA RECLAMATION PROJECT IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 1.5 MILES SOUTH WEST OF THE CITY BEACON, IOWA. THEAPPROXIMATELY 28.2 ACRE ABANDONED MINE LAND (AML) SITE WAS MINED PRIOR TO 1977. THE RECLAMATION PROJECT WILLELIMINATE THE COAL MINING FEATURES THAT PRESENT A DANGER TO THE HEALTH AND SAFETY OF THE PUBLIC AND RESULTINGACID MINE DRAINAGE. THE SITE IS 2 MILES FROM THE DES MOINES RIVER, WHICH IS ACTIVELY USED FOR RECREATION AND THECURRENT CONDITION OF THE SITE NEGATIVELY IMPACTS AN UN NAMED TRIBUTARY OF DRAINAGE DITCH NUMBER 2. THIS DRAINAGETHEN FLOWS SOUTHWEST INTO A SMALL UNNAMED TRIBUTARY WHICH FLOWS INTO THE DES MOINES RIVER. THE GOAL OF THEPROJECT IS TO RECLAIM THE PROJECT AREA TO ALLEVIATE AML PRIORITY FEATURES AND ESTABLISH A PERMANENT SEEDING TOSTABILIZE THE SITE.THE SITE DESIGN RE ESTABLISHES PRE MINING DRAINAGE PATTERNS INCLUDING ONE SMALL DRAINAGE WAYS AND WETLANDS.ACCORDING TO THE PROJECT DESIGN, CONSTRUCTION WILL ABATE ALL THE HAZARDOUS ABANDONED MINE LAND FEATURES. THECONSTRUCTION CONTRACT WILL CLEAR, RE GRADE AND RE VEGETATE APPROXIMATELY 28.2 ACRES USING THE HYBRID DESIGN FORRECLAMATION. THIS METHOD USES CONVENTIONAL RECLAMATION WITH TERRACES, TILES, AND INTAKE RISERS. THEN THERE WILLBE SECTIONS OF THE PROJECT THAT WILL USE NATURAL REGRADE, WHERE THE ENGINEER S DESIGN MIMICS FUNCTIONS OF NATURALLANDSCAPE THAT WOULD EVOLVE OVER TIME. THIS APPROACH RECLAIMS LAND BY DESIGNING NATURAL LANDSCAPE WITH STABILITYAGAINST EROSION BUILT INTO THE SITE AND WATER IS ALLOWED TO TRAVEL WHERE IT WOULD TRAVEL NATURALLY. THERE ALSOWILL BE 1.7 ACRES OF WETLANDS CONSTRUCTED ON SITE TO HELP WITH THE TREATMENT OF AMD, AND SEDIMENT CONTROL BEFORELEAVING THE SITE. THE IOWA AML PROGRAM HAS OVERSEEN MORE THAN 53 SIMILAR, AND SUCCESSFUL, RECLAMATION AND AMDREMEDIATION PROJECTS.NO INDIVIDUAL, BUSINESS OR POLITICAL SUBDIVISION HAS ANY LEGAL RESPONSIBILITY TO RECLAIM THE SITE. WATERSHEDCOOPERATIVE AGREEMENT PROGRAM (WCAP) FUNDS WILL BE MATCHED BY STATE AND LOCAL FUNDS TO COMPLETE THE MCCREARECLAMATION PROJECT. PATHFINDERS RCAND D WILL WORK WITH THE STATE OF IOWA S AML PROGRAM TO RECLAIM THE SITE. FUNDSWILL BE USED FOR EARTHMOVING, WATER AND SOIL NEUTRALIZATION, AND SEEDING ACTIVITIES TO ELIMINATE THE ACID MINEDRAINAGE ORIGINATING FROM THIS SITE. THE TOTAL RECLAMATION CONSTRUCTION COST IS ESTIMATED AT  730,300.00. TOTALPROJECT COSTS ARE ESTIMATED AT  832,763.00.UPON COMPLETION OF RECLAMATION, WILDLIFE HABITAT AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES WILL BE ENHANCED, PROVIDINGECONOMIC AND HEALTH BENEFITS TO ALL IOWANS. RECLAMATION WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT WATER QUALITY AND SOIL HEALTH ONTHE SITE, AS WELL AS, IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND SOIL HEALTH IN ADJACENT WATERBODIES AND FIELDS IN THE COUNTY OVERTIME THROUGH THE INTERCONNECTEDNESS OF THE WATER CYCLE AND SOIL SYSTEMS.

PROGRAM: NOT-FOR-PROFIT ACID MINE DRAINAGE (AMD) RECLAMATIONAWARD PURPOSE: FUNDING ASSISTS LOCAL QUALIFIED NOT-FOR-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS TO BEGIN ACTUAL CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS TO IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY OF STREAMS IMPACTED BY AMD. LANDS AND WATER ELIGIBLE FOR RECLAMATION OR DRAINAGE ABATEMENT EXPENDITURES UNDER SECTION 404 OF PUBLIC LAW 95-87 (THE ACT), AS AMENDED, ARE THOSE WHICH WERE MINED FOR COAL OR WHICH WERE AFFECTED BY SUCH MINING, WASTE BANKS, COAL PROCESSING, OR OTHER COAL MINING PROCESSES, EXCEPT AS PROVIDED FOR UNDER SECTION 411 OF THE ACT PRIOR TO AUGUST 3, 1977, AND FOR WHICH THERE IS NO CONTINUING RECLAMATION RESPONSIBILITY UNDER STATE OR OTHER FEDERAL LAWS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: CONTINUING THE EFFORT TO REMEDIATE THE CHARTIERS CREEK WATERSHED BY CONTINUING THE STREAM SEALING EFFORTS ALREADY COMPLETED, THIS PROJECT INCLUDES ADDITIONAL STREAM SEALING FOR THE STREAM BEDS FLOWING INTO FISHING RUN, THROUGH THE HISTORICALLY MINED DEPRESSION UPSTREAM AND TO THE WEST OF THE COMPLETED STREAM SEALING ALONG FISHING RUN. THE FISHING RUN STREAM SEALING PROJECT WILL CONSIST OF MINOR, TEMPORARY CONSTRUCTION TO CREATE AN IMPROVED STREAM BED. TO COMPLETE THE STREAM SEALING PROJECT, THE SUBSTRATE WILL BE REMOVED FROM THE STREAM BOTTOM AND STOCKPILED, AN IMPERMEABLE MEMBRANE LAYER WILL BE ADDED WHICH COULD INCLUDE A COMBINATION OF GEOSYNTHETIC LINER AND CLAY, AND THEN THE SUBSTRATE WILL BE REPLACED.EXPECTED DELIVERABLES OR OUTCOMES: FOR YEARS IT HAS ALWAYS BEEN THE INTENT OF THE LOCAL COMMUNITY TO CLEAN UP THE CHARTIERS CREEK WATERSHED. THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS STREAM SEALING WOULD FURTHER AID IN THE WATERSHED CLEANUP. THIS PROJECT WILL DEMONSTRATE THE PROGRESSION OF THE OVERALL GOAL, WHICH IS THE RESTORATION OF THE CHARTIERS CREEK WATERSHED.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE FULL IMPACT OF THE RESTORATION WORK COMPLETED THUS FAR IS POWERFUL. THE WATER THAT ONCE RAN ORANGE, LADEN WITH IRON AND OTHER METALS, ARE FLOWING STRONG AND CLEAR DOWN THE SAME STREAM BED. SUCH A DRAMATIC CHANGE INDICATES THE SUCCESS OF THE PROJECT, AND WE SEEK TO CONTINUE THIS WORK ON THE CONTRIBUTING STREAMS ALONG FISHING RUN.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES (IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT TIME OF AWARD): N/A

PROGRAM: NOT-FOR-PROFIT ACID MINE DRAINAGE (AMD) RECLAMATIONAWARD PURPOSE: FUNDING ASSISTS LOCAL QUALIFIED NOT-FOR-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS TO BEGIN ACTUAL CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS TO IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY OF STREAMS IMPACTED BY AMD. LANDS AND WATER ELIGIBLE FOR RECLAMATION OR DRAINAGE ABATEMENT EXPENDITURES UNDER SECTION 404 OF PUBLIC LAW 95-87 (THE ACT), AS AMENDED, ARE THOSE WHICH WERE MINED FOR COAL OR WHICH WERE AFFECTED BY SUCH MINING, WASTE BANKS, COAL PROCESSING, OR OTHER COAL MINING PROCESSES, EXCEPT AS PROVIDED FOR UNDER SECTION 411 OF THE ACT PRIOR TO AUGUST 3, 1977, AND FOR WHICH THERE IS NO CONTINUING RECLAMATION RESPONSIBILITY UNDER STATE OR OTHER FEDERAL LAWS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: DREAM MOUNTAIN PASSIVE TREATMENT SYSTEM IMPROVEMENTS - PHASE II WILL INCREASE TREATMENT EFFICACY AT THE DREAM MOUNTAIN SITE AND WILL REMOVE A SIGNIFICANT SOURCE OF ACID MINE DRAINAGE (AMD) FROM MUDDY CREEK. ON AVERAGE (PRIOR TO PHASE I CONSTRUCTION), ACID MINE DRAINAGE LOADS ENTERING MUDDY CREEK FROM THE SITE ARE APPROXIMATELY 805.17 POUNDS PER DAY OF ACIDITY, 59.85 POUNDS PER DAY OF DISSOLVED ALUMINUM, 29.01 POUNDS PER DAY OF DISSOLVED IRON, AND 4.57 POUNDS PER DAY DISSOLVED MANGANESE. FRIENDS OF THE CHEAT AND OUR PARTNERS EXECUTED THE PHASE I OF THE DREAM MOUNTAIN PASSIVE TREATMENT SYSTEM IMPROVEMENTS TO CONVERT THE STEEL SLAG BED TO AN AUTO-FLUSHING VERTICAL FLOW POND AND CONVERT THE MIXING BASIN INTO A SETTLING POND IN 2021. HOWEVER, THERE WERE NOT ENOUGH FUNDS TO CONVERT WETLAND CELL 1 INTO A SECOND ALKALINITY SOURCE (LIMESTONE LEACH BED OR JENNINGS POND) OR REHABILITATE WETLAND CELL 2 AS ORIGINALLY PLANNED.EXPECTED DELIVERABLES OR OUTCOMES: THE OVERALL GOAL FOR MUDDY CREEK IS TO REMOVE THE STREAM FROM THE STATE'S LIST OF IMPAIRED STREAMS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE GOAL OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO RECOVER FISHABLE WATER NOT ADDRESSED BY OTHER RESTORATION EFFORTS IN THE WATERSHED THEREBY RECONNECTING THE UPPER FISHERY WITH THE QUICKLY IMPROVING LOWER SECTION OF MUDDY CREEK AND THE CHEAT RIVER.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES (IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT TIME OF AWARD): N/A

PROGRAM:NOT-FOR-PROFIT ACID MINE DRAINAGE (AMD) RECLAMATIONAWARD PURPOSE: FUNDING ASSISTS LOCAL QUALIFIED NOT-FOR-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS TO BEGIN ACTUAL CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS TO IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY OF STREAMS IMPACTED BY AMD. LANDS AND WATER ELIGIBLE FOR RECLAMATION OR DRAINAGE ABATEMENT EXPENDITURES UNDER SECTION 404 OF PUBLIC LAW 95-87 (THE ACT), AS AMENDED, ARE THOSE WHICH WERE MINED FOR COAL OR WHICH WERE AFFECTED BY SUCH MINING, WASTE BANKS, COAL PROCESSING, OR OTHER COAL MINING PROCESSES, EXCEPT AS PROVIDED FOR UNDER SECTION 411 OF THE ACT PRIOR TO AUGUST 3, 1977, AND FOR WHICH THERE IS NO CONTINUING RECLAMATION RESPONSIBILITY UNDER STATE OR OTHER FEDERAL LAWS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:DUE TO A LACK IN ELEVATION CHANGE ON THE SITE, THE DISCHARGE WILL BE PUT THROUGH A FLOW-SPLITTING POOL, THEN TO TWO LAYERED-STYLE VERTICAL FLOW PONDS THAT WILL HAVE A FEW FEET OF LIMESTONE WITH APPROXIMATELY 6" TO 1' OF COMPOST ON TOP AS WELL AS A WATER CAP. THE FINAL POND WILL BE AN AEROBIC WETLAND BEFORE DISCHARGING TO TWO LICK CREEK. DURING THE DESIGN PHASE OF THE PROJECT, STREAM RESTORATION INCORPORATED WILL DETERMINE IF IT IS POSSIBLE TO PUT IN A TIF AT THE BEGINNING OF THE SYSTEM TO PROMOTE LOW PH IRON REMOVAL. THE CONCEPTUAL DESIGN FOR THIS SYSTEM IS EXPECTED TO IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY OF THE DISCHARGE BEFORE IT ENTERS TWO LICK CREEK BETTER THAN THE CURRENT LIME DOSING SILO.EXPECTED DELIVERABLES OR OUTCOMES:PROPER TREATMENT OF THIS DISCHARGE CAN PREVENT APPROXIMATELY 60.3 TONS OF ACIDITY, FIVE TONS OF IRON (FE), AND FIVE TONS OF ALUMINUM (AI) PER YEAR FROM ENTERING TWO LICK CREEK. THIS WILL CONSEQUENTLY IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY AND BIOTA OF THIS REGIONALLY VALUABLE STREAM. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:THE WILD TROUT FISHERY OF TWO LICK CREEK SHOULD INCREASE SUBSTANTIALLY FROM DIRECT IMPROVEMENTS IN WATER QUALITY AND INDIRECT IMPROVEMENTS IN WATER FERTILITY AND MACROINVERTEBRATE POPULATIONS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES (IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT TIME OF AWARD): N/A

PROGRAM: NOT-FOR-PROFIT ACID MINE DRAINAGE (AMD) RECLAMATIONAWARD PURPOSE: FUNDING ASSISTS LOCAL QUALIFIED NOT-FOR-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS TO BEGIN ACTUAL CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS TO IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY OF STREAMS IMPACTED BY AMD. LANDS AND WATER ELIGIBLE FOR RECLAMATION OR DRAINAGE ABATEMENT EXPENDITURES UNDER SECTION 404 OF PUBLIC LAW 95-87 (THE ACT), AS AMENDED, ARE THOSE WHICH WERE MINED FOR COAL OR WHICH WERE AFFECTED BY SUCH MINING, WASTE BANKS, COAL PROCESSING, OR OTHER COAL MINING PROCESSES, EXCEPT AS PROVIDED FOR UNDER SECTION 411 OF THE ACT PRIOR TO AUGUST 3, 1977, AND FOR WHICH THERE IS NO CONTINUING RECLAMATION RESPONSIBILITY UNDER STATE OR OTHER FEDERAL LAWS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: WESTERN PENNSYLVANIA CONSERVANCY (WPC) AND HEDIN ENVIRONMENTAL HAVE PARTNERED TO DEVELOP A PROJECT TO COMPLETE MAINTENANCE ON MULTIPLE OXIC LIMESTONE BED (OLB) SYSTEMS TREATING ABANDONED MINE DRAINAGE IN WESTERN PENNSYLVANIA. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO DEVELOP A RECOMMENDED BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICE (BMP) FOR MAINTENANCE AT OTHER PROJECT LOCATIONS AND EVALUATE THE FEASIBILITY OF OLB SYSTEMS TO EFFECTIVELY REMOVE MANGANESE. THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE USE OF OXIC LIMESTONE SYSTEMS TO PROVIDE SUSTAINABLE LOW-COST TREATMENT OF CONTAMINATED MINE WATER IN PENNSYLVANIA AND NATIONWIDE. THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP MAINTENANCE PRACTICES AND PERFORMANCE GUIDELINES FOR PASSIVE OXIC LIMESTONE BED TREATMENT SYSTEMS.EXPECTED DELIVERABLES OR OUTCOMES: THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE MAINTENANCE OF EIGHT EXISTING OXIC LIMESTONE BEDS THAT WERE CONSTRUCTED WITH STATE AND FEDERAL FUNDS. A VARIETY OF AGGREGATE CLEANING PROCEDURES WILL BE UTILIZED, AND A BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICE WILL BE DEVELOPED. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO DOCUMENT THE TREATMENT PERFORMANCE OF OXIC LIMESTONE BEDS AND MEASURE THE EFFECTS OF MAINTENANCE (AGGREGATE CLEANING) ON THE REMOVAL OF ACIDITY AND METALS.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE ESTIMATED BENEFITS, BASED ON CURRENT EXPERIENCES WITH CLEANING PROJECTS, IS THE REMOVAL OF APPROXIMATELY 900 POUND PER DAY OF ACIDITY (160 TON/YR CACO3) AND THE GENERATION OF AN ADDITIONAL 900 POUND PER DAY OF ALKALINITY (160 TON/YR CACO3). THE PROJECT WILL ALSO RESTORE METAL REMOVAL CAPABILITIES TO THE MAINTAINED SYSTEMS, RESULTING IN THE REMOVAL OF 100-200 POUNDS PER DAY OF FE, AL, AND MN. THE BMP WILL ENABLE NONPROFIT AND GOVERNMENT GROUPS TO UNDERSTAND THE MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS OF THEIR PASSIVE SYSTEMS, PROVIDE CONTRACTORS WITH INFORMATION NEEDED TO PROVIDE LOW-COST SERVICES, AND ENABLE STATE AND FEDERAL FUNDS TO MORE EFFECTIVELY SUPPORT O&M ACTIVITIES AT PASSIVE SYSTEMS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES (IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT TIME OF AWARD): N/A

PROGRAM:NOT-FOR-PROFIT ACID MINE DRAINAGE (AMD) RECLAMATIONAWARD PURPOSE: FUNDING ASSISTS LOCAL QUALIFIED NOT-FOR-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS TO BEGIN ACTUAL CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS TO IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY OF STREAMS IMPACTED BY AMD. LANDS AND WATER ELIGIBLE FOR RECLAMATION OR DRAINAGE ABATEMENT EXPENDITURES UNDER SECTION 404 OF PUBLIC LAW 95-87 (THE ACT), AS AMENDED, ARE THOSE WHICH WERE MINED FOR COAL OR WHICH WERE AFFECTED BY SUCH MINING, WASTE BANKS, COAL PROCESSING, OR OTHER COAL MINING PROCESSES, EXCEPT AS PROVIDED FOR UNDER SECTION 411 OF THE ACT PRIOR TO AUGUST 3, 1977, AND FOR WHICH THERE IS NO CONTINUING RECLAMATION RESPONSIBILITY UNDER STATE OR OTHER FEDERAL LAWS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:THE PINE RUN DOSER WAS CONSTRUCTED IN 2012 TO TREAT AMD IN THE PINE RUN SUBWATERSHED OF SUNDAY CREEK. FOLLOWING CONSTRUCTION OF THE DOSER 17 NATIVE SPECIES OF FISH WERE FOUND AT A MONITORING SITE WHERE ZERO HAD BEEN FOUND PRIOR TO TREATMENT. CURRENTLY, ALL 14 MILES OF THE WEST BRANCH DOWNSTREAM OF THE DOSER MEET OUR PH TARGET OF 6.5 AND SHOW BIOLOGICAL IMPROVEMENT. WHILE THIS PROJECT HAS BEEN SUCCESSFUL AT REDUCING THE IMPACTS OF AMD AND IMPROVING BIOLOGICAL RECOVERY, CONSTANT ISSUES RELATED TO THE WATER DRIVEN SYSTEM HAVE REDUCED TREATMENT EFFICIENCY AND SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASED MAINTENANCE NEEDS AT THE SITE. RURAL ACTION (RA), WITH THE COOPERATION OF OHIO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES WILL COMPLETE THE PINE RUN DOSER ELECTRIC RETROFIT PROJECT (PR-SL-35), WHEREIN AN ELECTRICALLY DRIVEN DOSING MECHANISM WILL BE RETROFITTED ONTO THE EXISTING PINE RUN DOSER SILO.EXPECTED DELIVERABLES OR OUTCOMES: THE PROPOSED PROJECT, RETROFITTING THE DOSER WITH AN ELECTRICAL DOSING SYSTEM, WILL INCREASE TREATMENT EFFICIENCY OF THE PINE RUN DOSER.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES:DOWNSTREAM IMPROVEMENTS IN WATER QUALITY AND BIOLOGICAL POPULATIONS TO BE SUSTAINED. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES (IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT TIME OF AWARD): N/A

PROGRAM: NOT-FOR-PROFIT ACID MINE DRAINAGE (AMD) RECLAMATIONAWARD PURPOSE: FUNDING ASSISTS LOCAL QUALIFIED NOT-FOR-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS TO BEGIN ACTUAL CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS TO IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY OF STREAMS IMPACTED BY AMD. LANDS AND WATER ELIGIBLE FOR RECLAMATION OR DRAINAGE ABATEMENT EXPENDITURES UNDER SECTION 404 OF PUBLIC LAW 95-87 (THE ACT), AS AMENDED, ARE THOSE WHICH WERE MINED FOR COAL OR WHICH WERE AFFECTED BY SUCH MINING, WASTE BANKS, COAL PROCESSING, OR OTHER COAL MINING PROCESSES, EXCEPT AS PROVIDED FOR UNDER SECTION 411 OF THE ACT PRIOR TO AUGUST 3, 1977, AND FOR WHICH THERE IS NO CONTINUING RECLAMATION RESPONSIBILITY UNDER STATE OR OTHER FEDERAL LAWS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: TO DATE, TWO TREATMENT SYSTEMS, LAUREL RUN #1 (2001) AND LAUREL RUN #2 (2005) HAVE BEEN INSTALLED TO ADDRESS AMD ISSUES IN LAUREL RUN, A TRIBUTARY TO THE MAINSTEM OF BLACKLICK CREEK THAT ENTERS JUST UPSTREAM OF JOSEPHINE, PA. WATER MONITORING OF LAUREL RUN HAS DEMONSTRATED SIGNIFICANT IMPROVEMENT IN WATER QUALITY DUE TO THE TWO PASSIVE SYSTEMS. WHILE IT MAY BE POSSIBLE TO PROLONG THE LIFE OF THE 20-YEAR-OLD SYSTEM THROUGH STIRRING OF THE EXISTING TREATMENT MEDIA AND PERFORMANCE OF OTHER MAINTENANCE IN THE SHORT-TERM, BASED ON THE EXISTING DESIGN AND PAST MAINTENANCE ISSUES, THE BEST COURSE OF ACTION IS TO REHABILITATE THE SYSTEM AND POTENTIALLY IMPROVE THE DESIGN BASED ON THE MOST RECENT UNDERSTANDING OF PASSIVE TREATMENT TECHNOLOGY. IN ADDITION, THE SYSTEM CAN LIKELY BE EXPANDED TO INCREASE THE AMOUNT OF DISCHARGE TO BE TREATED WITH LESS FREQUENT EPISODES OF UNTREATED WATER REACHING THE STREAM. THIS PROJECT WILL DESIGN, PERMIT, AND REHABILITATE/EXPAND THE LAUREL RUN #1 PASSIVE TREATMENT SYSTEM. CONSTRUCTION WILL FOCUS PRIMARILY ON RECONFIGURING TWO OF THE EXISTING VERTICAL FLOW PONDS AND EXPANDING A THIRD. NEW PIPING AND TREATMENT MEDIA WILL BE INSTALLED.EXPECTED DELIVERABLES OR OUTCOMES: THIS PROJECT IS EXPECTED TO REHABILITATE THE LAUREL RUN #1 PASSIVE TREATMENT SYSTEM. ONCE COMPLETED THE SYSTEM IS EXPECTED TO TREAT AN ESTIMATED 55 MILLION GALLONS OF AMD PER YEAR RESULTING IN THE NEUTRALIZATION OF OVER 50,000 LB/YEAR OF ACIDITY AND THE PREVENTION OF ABOUT 3,000 LB/YEAR OF IRON AND 4,000 LB/YEAR OF ALUMINUM FROM ENTERING LAUREL RUN, WHICH IS IDENTIFIED AS AN IMPAIRED STREAM ON THE PENNSYLVANIA INTEGRATED WATERS REPORT. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: RESTORING THE TREATMENT SYSTEM WILL HELP TO MAINTAIN THE IMPROVEMENT GAINS TO THE WATER QUALITY AND AQUATIC LIFE IN LAUREL RUN. THE NEW SYSTEM IS EXPECTED TO DISCHARGE BETTER WATER QUALITY MORE CONSISTENTLY THAN THE EXISTING SYSTEM, WHICH SHOULD LEAD TO FURTHER IMPROVEMENTS.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES (IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT TIME OF AWARD): N/A

PROGRAM: NOT-FOR-PROFIT ACID MINE DRAINAGE (AMD) RECLAMATIONAWARD PURPOSE: FUNDING ASSISTS LOCAL QUALIFIED NOT-FOR-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS TO BEGIN ACTUAL CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS TO IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY OF STREAMS IMPACTED BY AMD. LANDS AND WATER ELIGIBLE FOR RECLAMATION OR DRAINAGE ABATEMENT EXPENDITURES UNDER SECTION 404 OF PUBLIC LAW 95-87 (THE ACT), AS AMENDED, ARE THOSE WHICH WERE MINED FOR COAL OR WHICH WERE AFFECTED BY SUCH MINING, WASTE BANKS, COAL PROCESSING, OR OTHER COAL MINING PROCESSES, EXCEPT AS PROVIDED FOR UNDER SECTION 411 OF THE ACT PRIOR TO AUGUST 3, 1977, AND FOR WHICH THERE IS NO CONTINUING RECLAMATION RESPONSIBILITY UNDER STATE OR OTHER FEDERAL LAWS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE TANOMA AMD TREATMENT SYSTEM IS LOCATED IN THE HEAD WATERS OF CROOKED CREEK IN INDIANA COUNTY. THE TREATMENT SYSTEM WAS INSTALLED IN THE EARLY 90'S BY DEP, RESULTING IN THE ELIMINATION OF 23 TONS/YEAR OF IRON BEING DISCHARGED INTO CROOKED CREEK. IN THE LAST FEW YEARS THE PASSIVE TREATMENT SYSTEM HAS BECOME INEFFECTIVE DUE TO THE INABILITY OF THE CURRENT SYSTEM TO GENERATE ENOUGH IRON OXIDATION IN THE FIRST SETTLING POND. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONSTRUCT STRUCTURES WITHIN THE SYSTEM'S FOOTPRINT TO ALLOW A SHALLOW SHEET FLOW OF THE INFLUENT INTO THE FIRST POND. THIS WILL INCREASE THE OXIDATION AND GAS EXCHANGE AND ASSURE MORE RAPID IRON OXIDATION. IN ADDITION, THE PROJECT HOPES TO DECREASE THE SPEED OF THE WATER FLOW TO OBTAIN MAXIMUM SOLIDS PRECIPITATION THROUGH THE USE OF ADDITIONAL BAFFLE CURTAINS IN THE FIRST TWO PONDS. THE PROJECT MAY ALSO FIND THAT DREDGING A PORTION OF THE EXISTING IRON FROM THE INITIAL SETTLING PONDS WILL BE REQUIRED TO INCREASE THE RETENTION TIME.EXPECTED DELIVERABLES OR OUTCOMES: THIS PROJECT'S GOAL IS TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF THE WATER DISCHARGING FROM THE TANOMA PASSIVE TREATMENT SYSTEM AS IT ENTERS CROOKED CREEK, ESPECIALLY IN THE WINTER MONTHS WHEN THE PLANTS IN THE WETLANDS HAVE DIED AND INFLUENT WATER FLOW IS GREATER. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE DECREASED IRON CONCENTRATION IN CROOKED CREEK WILL BE A BENEFIT TO THE INDIANA COUNTY MUNICIPAL SERVICES AUTHORITY'S CROOKED CREEK PLANT THAT MAINTAINS A DRINKING WATER INTAKE APPROXIMATELY 10 MILES DOWNSTREAM. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES (IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT TIME OF AWARD): N/A

PROGRAM: NOT-FOR-PROFIT ACID MINE DRAINAGE (AMD) RECLAMATIONAWARD PURPOSE: FUNDING ASSISTS LOCAL QUALIFIED NOT-FOR-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS TO BEGIN ACTUAL CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS TO IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY OF STREAMS IMPACTED BY AMD. LANDS AND WATER ELIGIBLE FOR RECLAMATION OR DRAINAGE ABATEMENT EXPENDITURES UNDER SECTION 404 OF PUBLIC LAW 95-87 (THE ACT), AS AMENDED, ARE THOSE WHICH WERE MINED FOR COAL OR WHICH WERE AFFECTED BY SUCH MINING, WASTE BANKS, COAL PROCESSING, OR OTHER COAL MINING PROCESSES, EXCEPT AS PROVIDED FOR UNDER SECTION 411 OF THE ACT PRIOR TO AUGUST 3, 1977, AND FOR WHICH THERE IS NO CONTINUING RECLAMATION RESPONSIBILITY UNDER STATE OR OTHER FEDERAL LAWS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: WESTERN PENNSYLVANIA COALITION FOR ABANDONED MINE RECLAMATION IS SERVING AS THE APPLICANT FOR A PROJECT LOCATED WITHIN THE CITY OF ST. MARYS, ELK COUNTY, PENNSYLVANIA TITLED: WEST CREEK AMD TREATMENT SYSTEM INSTALLATION. THE TREATMENT SYSTEM IS DESIGNED TO TREAT FOUR MINE DISCHARGE SITES. THE SYSTEM IS SPATIALLY DIVIDED INTO TWO DISTINCT TREATMENT AREAS BASED ON THE LOCATIONS OF THE ACID MINE DRAINAGE DISCHARGE SOURCES. TREATMENT AREA 1 IS THE LARGER OF THE TWO AREAS AND TREATS THREE DISCHARGES. TREATMENT AREA 1 IS DESIGNED TO USE A TERRACED IRON FORMATION (TIFF) AND A JENNINGS- STYLE VERTICAL FLOW POND (JVFP), WHICH HAS A 20 YEAR- DESIGN LIFE. THE TIFF PROVIDES A LOW- COST TREATMENT THAT WILL HELP TO PROLONG THE LIFE OF THE JVFP THROUGH THE PRECIPITATION OF A PORTION OF THE IRON BEFORE IT REACHES THE FIRST ALKALINITY GENERATING COMPONENT. THIS HELPS TO PRESERVE THE HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY AND LONG- TERM FUNCTIONALITY OF THE JVFP TREATMENT MEDIA. TREATMENT AREA 2 IS DESIGNED TO TREAT ONE DISCHARGE USING AN ANOXIC LIMESTONE DRAIN, WHICH HAS A LIFETIME OF 20 YEARS.EXPECTED DELIVERABLES OR OUTCOMES: TREATMENT AREA 1 (DISCHARGES WC2, WC3, WC4): INSTALLATION OF A TERRACED IRON FORMATION (TIFF) WHICH SERVES AS A COLLECTION CHANNEL TO CAPTURE THE DIFFUSE SEEP ZONE, AND PROVIDES A MEANS FOR LOW-PH IRON REMOVAL TO OCCUR PRIOR TO TREATMENT IN THE SUBSEQUENT PRIMARY ALKALINITY GENERATING TREATMENT COMPONENT, WHICH IS THE JENNINGS STYLE VERTICAL FLOW POND (JVFP). TREATMENT AREA 2 (DISCHARGE WC6): INSTALLATION OF AN ANOXIC LIMESTONE DRAIN (ALD) WHICH ALLOWS FOR OXIDATION, PRECIPITATION, SETTLING, AND STORAGE OF IRON SOLIDS PRIOR TO THE ATER DISCHARGING INTO WEST CREEK.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT ANY RESIDENCE WITHIN THE FOUR MUNICIPALITIES OF THE CITY OF ST. MARYS, EMPORIUM BOROUGH, JONES TOWNSHIP, AND SHIPPEN TOWNSHIP, BETWEEN ELK AND CAMERON COUNTY. BENEFITS WILL BE ABLE TO BE SEEN IN THE UPPER REACHES OF THE SINNEMAHONING RIVER IN THE SUSQUEHANNA WATERSHED.SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES (IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT TIME OF AWARD): N/A
